Graphical abstract Metal-enzyme integrated catalysts combine the high selectivity of enzyme catalysts with the broad substrate spectrum of metal catalysts and offer tremendous possibilities for chemoenzymatic cascade processes. However, the rational design of microenvironments in nanostructures that make metals and enzymes compatible for efficient activity still remains challenging. In this report, a nanocomposite catalyst was fabricated by integrating ultrafine Pd nanoparticles (Pd NPs) and Candida antarctica lipase B (CALB) on the hydrophobic polydopamine-coated SiO2 (SP) to enhance the compatibility of enzyme-metal catalysts. In detail, Pd NPs were in situ reduced by PDA on the SP surface, and the obtained SP-loaded Pd (Pd/SP) was hydrophobically modified by octadecyltrimethoxysilane for the subsequent adsorption immobilization of CALB to prepare the integrated catalyst, CALB/mPd/SP. The hydrophobic PDA coating on SiO2 not only stabilized the loaded ultrasmall Pd nanoparticles but also facilitated the activation of the immobilized lipase, which helped to improve the cascade catalytic efficiency of CALB/mPd/SP. Afterward, CALB/mPd/SP was used in a one-pot dynamic kinetic resolution (DKR) reaction of α-phenylethylamine with high conversion (>99 %), selectivity (93.9 %), and eep (>99 %). After 25 days of storage and 5 h of sonication, CALB/mPd/SP exhibited no significant reduction in the DKR catalytic activity. This study proposed a simple and sustainable method for the preparation of enzyme-metal cascade catalysts to enhance their stability and achieve significantly increased activity through interfacial microenvironmental modulation. Keywords Interfacial biocatalysis Microenvironments tailoring Lipase interfacial activation Enzyme-metal hybrid catalyst Cooperative catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the past decades, metal-enzyme integrated catalysts have been employed in a broad application prospect in organic synthesis due to the advantages of combining the high selectivity of enzymes with the multifunctionality of metal catalysts [1] and avoiding the isolation of intermediates [2]. However, the compatibility of metal nanoparticles (NPs) and enzymes (e.g., toxicity of metals to enzymes and incompatibility of reaction conditions) [3], cross-inhibition of substrates and intermediates [4], and poor reusability severely limit the extensive application of metal-enzyme integrated catalysts. In order to solve the above issues, the integration strategy was developed to reduce the mass transfer resistance, improve the synergistic catalytic efficiency, and avoid the direct contact of the two catalysts by co-immobilizing the enzyme and metal catalysts [5,6]. However, recent studies of this strategy mainly focus on novel porous materials with complex compositions and structures (e.g., metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) [7], covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [8], C3N4 [9], etc.) rather than on the regulation of reaction microenvironments and active sites [10,11]. Therefore, the low activity of the co-immobilized enzymes and metal catalysts remains a major hindrance to the application of metal-enzyme integrated catalysts. Tailoring the microenvironment around catalysts could be regarded as an important method to regulate the catalytic activity of metal-enzyme integrated catalysts [12]. On the one hand, the microenvironment of catalysts could result in the desired affinity for the corresponding substrates and enrich them to improve the catalytic performance [13]. On the other hand, some enzymes like lipases could be activated under the hydrophobic microenvironment, which was also called “interfacial activation” [14]. When lipase comes into contact with a hydrophobic interface, hydrophobic interactions induce the opening of the “lid” structure, this conformational change allows the catalytic triad of lipase to contact the substrate, thus significantly increasing its catalytic activity [15,16]. As an example, Zhao et al. co-immobilized Pd nanoparticles (NPs) and Candida antarctica lipase B (CALB) in the pores and surface of COF with different functional groups (−ONa, –OH, and −OMe), respectively [6]. The metal-enzyme integrated catalysts integrated by COF-OMe showed the highest cascade catalytic performance due to the hydrophobic microenvironment, which could modulate the conformation of CALB, electronic state of Pd NPs, and the substrate affinity to the integrated catalyst. Moreover, tailoring the microenvironment around the catalyst presents another potential strategy to prevent metal nanoparticle aggregation in/on carriers. Huang et al. reported that the polydimethylsiloxane coating on UIO-66-encapsulated Pd could prevent the aggregation of NPs, leading to excellent catalytic recovery performance [13]. As a representative example of metal-enzyme cascade catalytic system, dynamic kinetic resolution (DKR) combines lipase-catalyzed kinetic resolution (KR) with Pd-catalyzed racemization [17] and has been widely used for the asymmetric synthesis of chiral amines [18–20]. In this study, we report an interfacial modification method based on the hydrophobic PDA coating to improve the compatibility of the integrated lipase and Pd NPs for the DKR reaction of chiral amine. In detail, the ultrafine Pd NPs were firstly in situ reduced and highly dispersed on the polydopamine (PDA) shells of SiO2 NPs to obtain the nanocatalyst (denoted as Pd/SP). The particle size and dispersion degree of the ultrafine NPs could be regulated by changing precursor concentration. Afterward, Pd/SP was modified by octadecyltrimethoxysilane (TMODS) to construct a hydrophobic surface and then utilized for CALB immobilization. The tailored hydrophobic interface could not only stabilize the Pd NPs to avoid agglomeration but also provide an interfacially active hydrophobic microenvironment for CALB [21]. Finally, the obtained hybrid catalyst, CALB/mPd/SP, was used for the one-pot DKR reaction of α-phenylethylamine. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials All of the following chemicals were commercially available and used without further treatment. Silicon dioxide (SiO2), dopamine hydrochloride (98 %), palladium acetate (Pd(OAc)2, 99.9 %), TMODS (95 %), Pd/C (5 wt%), (S)-alpha-phenylethylamine (99 %), (R)-alpha-phenylethylamine (98 %), alpha-phenylethylamine (≥98 %), ethyl methoxyacetate (98 %), anhydrous sodium carbonate (99.5 %), and molecular sieve are purchased from Aladdin Industrial Inc. (Shanghai, China). Anhydrous ethanol, toluene, and ethyl acetate (99.5 %) are purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Novozym 435 and Candida antarctica lipase B (CALB) are provided by Beijing Novozymes Investment Co. Ltd. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The size and distribution of the loaded Pd NPs were analyzed using a transmission electron microscope (TEM, Hitachi H800, Japan) equipped with an energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS). X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out on a Bruker D8-Advance with a Cu Kα x-ray source. Ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy spectra were performed on a Cary60 (UV–vis, Agilent) spectrophotometer. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, Nicolet-iS5, Thermo Fisher Scientific) was used to determine the surface functionalities of the samples. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) was used to determine the content of Pd, and samples were analyzed using an Optima 5300DV. The distribution of CALB labeled with fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) was investigated by confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM, TCS SP5II, Leica). A thermogravimetric analyzer (TG, STA449F5) from NETZSCH, Germany, was used to test the quality of the samples in relation to the temperature by means of programmed temperature control. The Zeta Potential Analyzer (ZS990, Zetasizer Advance) was used to evaluate the surface charges of individual samples. The elemental composition of the composite catalysts and the valence characterization of Pd were analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250xi, Thermo Fisher). 2.3 Synthesis of Pd/SP SP was synthesized following the method reported by Veisi et al. [22] with some modifications. SiO2 (0.5 g) was dispersed in Tris-HCl (pH 8.5, 10 mM) and then DA-HCl was added in the dispersion under stirring, the obtained mixture was gradually stirred for 16 h at room temperature. The precipitation was collected after centrifugation, washed three times with deionized water, and dried to obtain SP. The synthesis of Pd/SP occurred through in situ reduction using Pd(OAc)2 as the Pd precursor. SP was dispersed in 200 mL deionized water, and a certain amount of Pd(OAc)2 solution was added drop-by-drop under stirring, while the mass ratio of SP to palladium precursor was 5:1. The obtained mixture was stirred for 7 h at room temperature. The precipitation product was collected at 8000 rpm and dried under vacuum for 12 h. 2.4 Immobilization of CALB on mPd/SP Pd/SP (0.5 g) was dispersed in 24 mL of toluene and 1.18 mL of TMODS was added to the suspension. After ultrasonication for 10 min, the mixture was stirred and refluxed at 90 °C for 15 h. The precipitation was collected by centrifugation, washed with water and ethanol, and dried in a vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h. The black powder with a hydrophobically modified surface was obtained and denoted as mPd/SP. CALB was immobilized on mPd/SP by physical adsorption. A certain amount of mPd/SP and CALB were mixed and dispersed in 50 mL of PB and evenly shaken for 8 h at the speed of 220 rpm at 30 °C. The product was collected at 8000 rpm, washed with PB, and freeze-dried overnight to obtain CALB/mPd/SP. 2.5 Evaluation of catalytic activity DKR performance test. DKR reaction was carried out in a 25 mL Schlenk flask, the reaction system containing a certain amount of CALB/mPd/SP, 0.33 mmol of α-phenylethylamine, 0.66 mmol of ethyl methoxyacetate, 2 mL of toluene solution, Na2CO3, molecular sieves and hydrogen pressure of 0.01 MPa at 70 °C, the system pressure was realized with a 5 % H2/Ar gas mixture. The products were separated by centrifugation at the end of the reaction, the obtained supernatant was filtered through a 0.22 µm filter, after which the relative amounts of α-phenylethylamine, 2-methoxy-N(1-phenylethyl)acetamide and reaction by-products were analyzed using a gas phase chromatography equipped with a CP-ChirasilDex CB chiral column (25 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 µm). Enzyme activity evaluation. The transesterification reaction of p-nitrophenyl palmitate (p-NPP) [23,24] has been widely used as a typical reaction to assess the activity of lipase. The enzyme solution was mixed with 2 mL of p-NPP (1 mM, pH 8.0) solution and the mixture was reacted at 60 °C for 5 min, the reaction supernatant was collected at 8000 rpm and the absorbance value at 400 nm was measured using UV spectrophotometer. One enzyme activity unit (U) was defined as the amount of enzyme required to catalyze the hydrolysis of p-NPP to produce 1 μmol of p-nitrophenol (p-NP) per minute. The enzymatic activity of CALB/mPd/SP was determined using the same method: (1) Enzyme activity (U/g)= 1000 × N × V × y k × t × m where N refers to the dilution factor, V refers to the total volume of the reaction system (mL), y refers to the measured absorbance, k refers to the coefficient of the standard curve of 4-NP, t refers to the reaction time of the system (min), and m refers to the immobilized amount of enzyme (mg). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characteristics of CALB/mPd/SP During the synthesis of Pd/SP (Fig. 1 ), DA was first deposited on the SiO2 surface by a multilevel oxidation-autopolymerization-assembly strategy to form a PDA shell. Afterward, Pd precursors were anchored at the functional groups on the PDA surface and then in situ reduced to ultrafine Pd NPs. In order to construct a compatible interfacial microenvironment for Pd NPs and CALB, TMODS was utilized to modify Pd/SP for the transformation of the surface property from hydrophilic to hydrophobic. Finally, CALB was immobilized on the surface of Pd/SP by physisorption to obtain CALB/mPd/SP. TEM images (Fig. 2 a and b) showed that SiO2 and SP exhibited a spherical morphology with an average particle size of about 20 nm, thus implying that the PDA coating had no obvious effects on the morphology of SiO2. Then the Pd precursor, Pd(OAc)2, was further employed to generate Pd NPs on the SP surface, and it can be observed in Fig. 2c that the ultrafine Pd NPs were uniformly distributed on the Pd/SP surface. The EDS images indicated the uniform distribution of Si, Pd and other elements in Pd/SP (Fig. 2d-i). In the FTIR spectrum Fig. 3 a, the broadband at 1119 cm−1 and 3466 cm−1 were attributed to the Si-O-Si and O–H stretching vibrations, which were characteristic peaks of SiO2. The peaks at 1625 cm−1 and 1403 cm−1 of the SP were related to the C=C stretching vibration and C-N stretching, respectively [25], which proved the successful PDA coating on SiO2. This was further supported by the TGA analysis (Fig. 3b), where the weight loss of SP was 3.5 wt% higher than SiO2 due to the carbonization of the coated PDA on SiO2 under high temperatures. The crystal structures of samples were further characterized by XRD (Fig. 3c). The XRD pattern of SP was consistent with that of SiO2, indicating that the PDA polymer coating exhibited no effect on the crystal structure of SiO2 [26]. For Pd/SP, the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 39.9°, 46.3°, and 67.8° corresponded to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0), and (2 2 0) crystal planes of palladium [27,28], respectively, demonstrating the loading of the Pd NPs on the SP surface. The XPS survey spectrum (Fig. 4 a) confirmed the presence of Si, C, O, N, and Pd elements in Pd/SP. The binding energies of 399.93 and 404.28 eV in the N 1s high-resolution spectrum of Pd/SP were attributed to the –NH– groups and –NH2 in the indole structure of PDA (Fig. 4b). The C 1s spectrum was convolved into five peaks at 284.8, 285.85, 287.7, 289.25, and 290.8 eV (Fig. 4c), corresponding to the C-C, C-N, C-OH, C=O, and O-C=OH moieties of the PDA, respectively, thus illustrating the successful coating of the PDA on SiO2. XPS analysis of the Pd 3d binding energy was performed to reveal the surface electronic states of Pd NPs in Pd/SP. The characteristic peaks of Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 could be observed on the high-resolution spectrum of Pd 3d (Fig. 4d), corresponding to the Pd0 (336.8 eV of Pd0 3d5/2 and 341.9 eV of Pd0 3d3/2) and Pd2+ (338.1 eV of Pd2+ 3d5/2 and 343.5 eV of Pd2+ 3d3/2) states [27,29]. The higher characteristic peak of Pd0 than Pd2+ implied that Pd2+ was not completely reduced, but Pd0 dominated the nanoparticles [30]. 3.2 DKR catalytic performance of Pd/SPX with Novozym 435 In order to achieve the optimal catalytic rate of Pd NPs, we then synthesized Pd/SPX with different Pd NPs contents (X meant the content of Pd NPs) by changing the mass ratio of SP to Pd(OAc)2. As shown in Fig. 5 a, the zeta potentials of SiO2 and SP were −17.9 and −28.1 mV, respectively. After Pd NPs loading, the surface potentials of Pd/SP gradually increased with the increase of the loading of Pd NPs, which might be ascribed to the conversion of phenolic hydroxyl groups to quinone groups during the in situ reduction of Pd ion, which further proved the mechanism of the reduction of metal ions by PDA [25,31]. The loading of Pd NPs on the Pd/SPX surface was further measured by ICP (Table S1), with the average diameter of Pd NPs calculated by particle size analysis. As depicted in Fig. 5b-g and b'-5g', when the mass ratio of Pd(OAc)2 to SP was 1:5, the loading and average particle size of Pd NPs were 7.71 wt% and 1.22 nm, respectively, with a DKR conversion of 56.9 % (Fig. 5h). Continuously increasing the mass ratio of Pd(OAc)2:SP to 1.6:5, the average particle size grew to 2.4 nm with 12.4 wt% loading of Pd NPs. The obvious aggregation of Pd NPs and the minor increase in DKR conversion under this condition may be attributed to the aggregation of Pd NPs, which resulted in the incomplete exposure of the active sites and the gradual saturation of the limited Pd catalytic capacity. For economic considerations, SP/Pd with 7.71 % Pd NPs was used for the subsequent DKR reaction. We first investigated the DKR reaction efficiency of SP@Pd7.71% when coupled with the commercial lipase Novozym 435. During the DKR reaction of α-phenylethylamine, the immobilized Pd catalyst continuously racemized (S)-phenylethylamine, while lipase catalyzed the conversion of (R)-phenylethylamine to amide, and the final product was evaluated and characterized by GC–MS. The catalytic data in Table S2 showed that the dosage of Novozym 435 had a small effect on the conversion and eep value. The selectivity showed a tendency to increase and then decrease with the increase of Novozym 435 dosage. This may be due to the fact that the catalytic rate of lipase was lower than that of Pd when the amount of Novozym 435 in the reaction was low, resulting in the conversion of the substrate to ethylbenzene as a by-product during racemization. In addition, the effect of Pd/SP amount on the DKR process of α-phenylethylamine was investigated (Table S3). The substrate conversion was incomplete when the Pd/SP dosage was lower than 15 mg and reached >99 % when Pd/SP dosage was over 15 mg. However, the selectivity showed a gradual decrease with the further increase of Pd/SP. This was attributed to the fact that the excess amount of racemization catalyst promoted the racemization reaction and at the same time promoted the competitive condensation reaction of secondary amines, which converted more intermediate products into ethylbenzene [17,32]. The stability of SP@Pd7.71% was then investigated by combining it with Novozym 435 for the DKR reaction of α-phenylethylamine. As depicted in Fig. S1a-S1b, the catalytic activity of SP@Pd7.71% exhibited no obvious after 5 h ultrasonic treatment and 50 days storage at room temperature, indicating the great mechanical stability of SP@Pd7.71%. The recyclability of SP@Pd7.71% was also examined by recovering and washing it with dry toluene after each cycle. It can be seen from Fig. S1c that the catalytic activity of SP@Pd7.71% did not change significantly. The morphology changes of SP@Pd7.71% after catalysis were confirmed by SEM (Fig. S1d), which indicated that there was no agglomeration of Pd NPs and the distribution and size of Pd NPs did not show significant changes after five batches for catalysis as compared to the original SP@Pd7.71% (Fig. S1c). 3.3 Fabrication and catalytic activity of the immobilized CALB on mPd/SP Considering that the hydrophobic surface is probably positively affecting the Pd NPs and CALB [6], the microenvironment of the metal-enzyme catalyst on the SP/Pd surface was further tailored. TMODS was utilized to transform the hydrophilic nature of the SP@Pd surface into hydrophobicity. The water contact angle of hydrophobic mPd/SP at different TMODS ratios was investigated, and the results were shown in Fig. 6 a. The highest water contact angle (154.8°) of mPd/SP was observed after the introduction of long alkane chains on the surface, while the pristine Pd/SP owned the lowest contact angle of 5.23°. This significant change in water contact angle revealed the successful grafting of alkane chains on mPd/SP. CALB was used as the resolution catalyst and immobilized on the surface of mPd/SP by physical adsorption. CALB/mPd/SP was fluorescently labeled by RhB to observe the distribution of lipase on the carrier. The FTIR spectra (Fig. 6b) showed new peaks at 1664 cm−1 and 1558 cm−1, which were attributed to the stretching vibrational peaks of amide I and amide II of CALB, respectively, thus proving the successful fabrication of CALB/mPd/SP. The red fluorescence of CALB/mPd/SP was clearly visible in the CLSM image (Fig. 6c), confirming the successful immobilization of CALB. In addition, TEM images showed (Fig. S2) that the modification of the Pd/SP surface by TMODS and the adsorption of CALB had no obvious effect on the morphology of Pd/SP. To study the effect of hydrophobic microenvironment on lipase immobilization, the effects of TMODS and CALB addition on enzyme loading capacity and immobilized enzyme activity were investigated. As shown in Fig. 6d, the enzyme loading was elevated from 21.8 mg/g to 100.3 mg/g when the molar ratio of TMODS to SP@Pd increased from 0 to 5.0, thus confirming the critical role of the hydrophobic microenvironment in immobilization. Notably, the relative activity of the immobilized enzyme was increased by 75 % (Fig. 5d), which could be attributed to the fact that when the CALB met the hydrophobic interface, the unique “lid” of the lipase presented an open conformation, which allowed the substrate to contact with the active site more efficiently. The effect of CALB addition on enzyme loading and activity was similar to that of TMODS (Fig. 6e). Considering the optimization results, the TMODS and CALB additions of 5.0 mmol/g and 140 mg/g, respectively, were selected for subsequent studies. 3.4 DKR catalytic performance of CALB/mPd/SP The obtained metal-enzyme cascade catalyst, CALB/mPd/SP, was employed for the DKR reaction of α-phenylethylamine, and the effect of CALB loading in CALB/mPd/SP on the DKR performance was evaluated. The data in Table 1 showed that as the CALB loading in CALB/mPd/SP increased, the conversion value of the DKR reaction increased accordingly with and high eep value, while the selectivity maintained <85 %. The reason might be that the rate of the racemization reaction was elevated when compared with the rate of CALB-catalyzed resolution, which resulted in the exacerbation of the side esterification reaction between (S)-phenylethylamine and acyl donor. In order to further improve the selectivity for efficient α-phenylethylamine DKR reaction, the racemization activity of Pd and the resolution activity of CALB were then matched by optimizing the content of Pd in CALB/mPd/SP [17]. As seen in Table S4, as the content of Pd NPs in CALB/mPd/SP increased from 0.87 % to 7.71 %, the conversion and eep value of the DKR reaction increased to >99 %, while the selectivity continuously dropped from 96.8 % to 84.9 %. Hence, the Pd loading of 2.88 % in CALB/mPd/SP was selected for the following experiments. The effect of reaction conditions on the cascade catalysis performance of CALB/mPd/SP was investigated. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the conversion yield increased rapidly while the selectivity and eep kept high values with the reaction proceeding, and when the reaction time was over 6 h, the conversion reached more than 99 %. The cascade catalysis performance of CALB/mPd/SP was then studied at different temperatures. As depicted in Fig. 7b, the conversion increased dramatically with the increasing temperature and reached >99 % at 70 °C with eep value of >98.9 %. However, the selectivity decreased gradually as the reaction temperature increased from 50 to 90 °C, which could be attributed to the fact that high temperature damaged the conformation of CALB and reduced the resolution efficiency. Meanwhile, high temperature also promoted the catalytic activity of the Pd NPs, which would further result in a decrease in selectivity. Fig. 7c reflected the effect of H2 pressure on the DKR performance of CALB/mPd/SP, the conversion and eep values remained above 98 % when H2 pressure was over 0.01 MPa, while the selectivity tended to decrease due to the inhibition of the dehydrogenation process of (S)-phenylethylamine by excessive pressure. Afterward, the catalytic performance of Pd-CALB hybrid catalyst based on SP before and after hydrophobic modification was compared to investigate the effect of interfacial hydrophilicity on the DKR performance. As shown in Fig. 7d, the conversion and selectivity of the DKR catalytic system containing CALB/Pd/SP were 39.4 % and 29.1 %, respectively, which were much lower than those of the CALB/mPd/SP system. This could be ascribed to two reasons, on the one hand, the “lid” of CALB opened when the CALB interacted with the hydrophobic interface, and the resulting relative activity was much higher than that of CALB on pristine PDA surface. On the other hand, the hydrophobic surface of CALB/mPd/SP was conducive to enriching the substrate and stabilizing the imine intermediate, which might promote α-phenylethylamine hydrogenation on the Pd surface and reduce the side reactions [33]. Moreover, compared with the integrated DKR catalysts reported in literatures, CALB/mPd/SP achieved a comparable DKR performance with the lowest Pd amount and a shorter reaction time (Table S5), demonstrating the advantages of the hydrophobic PDA coating-assisted fabrication of DKR catalyst. In terms of practical applicability, stability is an important indicator for evaluating DKR catalysts. The results showed that there was no significant change in the efficiency of the composite catalyst in catalyzing the DKR reaction within 5h of sonication (Fig. 8 a). Its storage stability was further investigated (Fig. 8b), which showed that the selectivity of the DKR reaction of CALB/mPd/SP decreased by only 2.3 % after 25 days of storage at 4 °C. To demonstrate the recyclability of the CALB/mPd/SP catalyst, six repetitive cycles of the reaction with α-phenylethylamine were performed (Fig. S3). After each cycle, the catalyst was washed twice with 1 mL of dry toluene by centrifugation. It was able to maintain a conversion of over 63.7 % with selectivity and eep values above 95 % after 6 repeated cycles. The results of the stability study indicate that CALB/mPd/SP could be a nonhomogeneous catalyst with great robustness. The catalytic performance of the CALB/mPd/SP was further investigated for the DKR reaction with different primary amines (Table S6). The experimental results showed that the CALB/mPd/SP exhibited excellent catalytic activities for the six tested substrates, with the conversion rate reaching 85–99 % and the eep value maintained at a high level of 88–99 %. The above results confirmed that CALB/mPd/SP has broad substrate applicability in the DKR reaction. 4 Conclusion In summary, we developed a nanocomposite catalyst, CALB/mPd/SP, by integrating ultrafine Pd NPs and CALB on the hydrophobic PDA-coated SiO2 for the DKR reaction of α-phenylethylamine. In detail, Pd NPs were in situ loaded on the PDA coating of SP, and the obtained Pd/SP was utilized as the matrix after hydrophobic modification for CALB adsorption to fabricate CALB/mPd/SP. The hydrophobic PDA coating not only stabilized the loaded ultrasmall Pd nanoparticles but also facilitated the interfacial activation of the immobilized lipase. Finally, CALB/mPd/SP was used for the dynamic kinetic resolution (DKR) reaction of α-phenylethylamine with high conversion (>99 %), selectivity (93.9 %), and eep (>99 %). After 25 days of storage and 5h of sonication, the cascade catalytic activity of CALB/mPd/SP exhibited no significant reduction. This work provides a new route for the development of biocompatible metal-enzyme integrated catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Metal-enzyme integrated catalysts combine the high selectivity of enzyme catalysts with the broad substrate spectrum of metal catalysts and offer tremendous possibilities for chemoenzymatic cascade processes. However, the rational design of microenvironments in nanostructures that make metals and enzymes compatible for efficient activity still remains challenging. In this report, a nanocomposite catalyst was fabricated by integrating ultrafine Pd nanoparticles (Pd NPs) and Candida antarctica lipase B (CALB) on the hydrophobic polydopamine-coated SiO2 (SP) to enhance the compatibility of enzyme-metal catalysts. In detail, Pd NPs were in situ reduced by PDA on the SP surface, and the obtained SP-loaded Pd (Pd/SP) was hydrophobically modified by octadecyltrimethoxysilane for the subsequent adsorption immobilization of CALB to prepare the integrated catalyst, CALB/mPd/SP. The hydrophobic PDA coating on SiO2 not only stabilized the loaded ultrasmall Pd nanoparticles but also facilitated the activation of the immobilized lipase, which helped to improve the cascade catalytic efficiency of CALB/mPd/SP. Afterward, CALB/mPd/SP was used in a one-pot dynamic kinetic resolution (DKR) reaction of α-phenylethylamine with high conversion (>99 %), selectivity (93.9 %), and eep (>99 %). After 25 days of storage and 5 h of sonication, CALB/mPd/SP exhibited no significant reduction in the DKR catalytic activity. This study proposed a simple and sustainable method for the preparation of enzyme-metal cascade catalysts to enhance their stability and achieve significantly increased activity through interfacial microenvironmental modulation.
